microsim.title: Cognitive Load Visualizer
microsim.description: Interactive visualization demonstrating the three types of cognitive load (intrinsic, extraneous, and germane) and their impact on working memory capacity. Users can adjust sliders to see how different load combinations affect learning effectiveness and explore optimal instructional design configurations.
microsim.subject: Educational Psychology
learning_objectives: Identify and distinguish between the three types of cognitive load
Explain how each type of cognitive load affects learning outcomes
Recognize when total cognitive load exceeds working memory capacity
Apply cognitive load principles to evaluate instructional design
Design learning materials that optimize cognitive load
prerequisites: Basic understanding of how learning works
microsim.author: Intelligent Textbooks Project

controls.name: Intrinsic Load
controls.description: Adjust the inherent difficulty of the content being learned

controls.name: Extraneous Load
controls.description: Adjust the mental effort wasted on poor instructional design

controls.name: Germane Load
controls.description: Adjust the mental effort devoted to learning processes

controls.name: Good Design Example
controls.description: Load an example showing optimal cognitive load balance

controls.name: Bad Design Example
controls.description: Load an example showing cognitive overload

controls.name: Reset to Default
controls.description: Return all sliders to their default values

feedback_mechanisms: Color changes (blue/orange/red) based on load level

assessment_suggestions: Ask students to identify which type of load each design element creates
Have students calculate total load from given scenarios
Request redesign of high-load materials to reduce extraneous load
Ask students to justify load estimates for specific learning materials
Have students create load profiles for different learner expertise levels
extension_activities: Analyze real textbooks or courses for cognitive load issues
Create before/after designs showing load reduction
Research how expertise changes intrinsic load
Design a study to measure cognitive load in learners
Apply multimedia learning principles to reduce extraneous load

theoretical_foundation.developers: John Sweller, Paul Chandler, Fred Paas
key_principles: Working memory has limited capacity (typically 4-7 chunks)
Long-term memory has virtually unlimited capacity
Learning requires transferring information from working to long-term memory
Cognitive load is additive across all three types
Effective design manages all three types of load
research_support: Meta-analyses show effect sizes of 0.4-1.0 for load reduction
Split-attention effect consistently demonstrates extraneous load impact
Worked example effect shows intrinsic load management
Expertise reversal effect demonstrates load relativity

common_misconceptions: More information is always better (ignores capacity limits)
Attractive design is more important than clear design (adds extraneous load)
All cognitive effort is productive (ignores extraneous load)
Content difficulty can't be managed (ignores chunking strategies)

accessibility.described_content: Interactive cognitive load visualizer with three adjustable load types and a capacity meter showing when working memory is overloaded
